did.abstract: The Carl Van Vechten Papers includes correspondence, writings, photographs, scrapbooks and albums, and artwork documenting Carl Van Vechten's activities as a writer, photographer, and patron of the arts.

langmaterial.language: Chiefly in English; some material in French and Spanish.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: Series I. Correspondence, Series II. Writings, Series III. Personal Papers, Series IV. Art, and Series V. Printed Material are open for research. As additional series are processed they will be opened to researchers. For additional information contact the processing archivists.
Box 176 is for research use only, and may not be duplicated.
Boxes 206-209, 213-217, 223: Restricted fragile material. For further information consult the appropriate curator.

Boxes 313-324: Restricted fragile material. Reference surrogates have been substituted in the main files with the exception of clippings relating to World War I and Edgar Saltus which were too fragile to be duplicated. For further information consult the appropriate curator.
Box 325: Restricted until 2035. For further information consult the appropriate curator.

bioghist.head: Carl Van Vechten (1880-1964)
bioghist.p: Carl Van Vechten was a writer, photographer, collector, and patron of the arts. Born in Cedar Rapids, Iowa, on June 17, 1880, Van Vechten developed an early interest in literature and the fine and performing arts. He attended the University of Chicago, and wrote for several Chicago newspapers before moving to New York City in 1906. Over the next five decades he established himself as a journalist, critic, novelist, photographer, and cultural icon. He wrote music, dance, and theater reviews in New York and Paris for The New York Times and The New York Press , and for magazines and journals including Trend , Vanity Fair , Crisis , New Republic , and Esquire . He authored numerous books including, Music After the Great War (1915), The Tiger in the House (1920), Peter Whiffle : His Life and Works (1922), The Blind-Bow Boy (1923), The Tattooed Countess (1924), Firecrackers (1925), Nigger Heaven (1926), Spider Boy (1928), Parties (1930), and Sacred and Profane Memories (1932), most of which were published by Alfred A. Knopf.

His 1907 marriage to Ann Snyder, a friend since his youth in Cedar Rapids, ended in divorce in 1912. On October 21, 1914 he married Fania Marinoff, an actress who had immigrated to the United States as a child from Russia. They were married for fifty years. A family inheritance received in 1927 provided Van Vechten with the means to support himself and Fania, and freed him to pursue his interests without financial constraints. During the 1920s, Van Vechten was introduced to members of the artistic and cultural movement that would become known as the Harlem Renaissance. He enjoyed frequenting the clubs, restaurants, and salons of Harlem, and he began to develop friendships among members of the Black community. His 1926 novel, Nigger Heaven , was inspired by his visits to Harlem and its residents.

Beginning in the early 1930s Van Vechten devoted much of his time to photography. In his home studio he produced hundreds of photographic portraits of his friends and acquaintances, as well as other world figures whom he photographed by invitation and by recommendations from mutual friends. He and Fania developed a large multicultural network of friends and acquaintances in New York, throughout the United States, and abroad. The Van Vechten apartment became a meeting place for established and developing writers, visual and performing artists, publishers, educators, social activists, and others. Throughout his life Van Vechten developed close friendships with women as well as intimate relationships with men.

As a collector, Van Vechten acquired important collections of books and manuscripts, particularly those relating to African-American arts and literature. In 1941, he established the James Weldon Johnson Memorial Collection of Negro Arts and Letters at Yale University, in honor of the writer and close friend who had died in 1938. In 1947, Van Vechten established the Anna Marble-Pollock Collection of Books about Cats at Yale. He also gave to Yale additional individual books and manuscripts, as well as a large group of his personal papers. He established and/or donated material to collections at other institutions including Fisk University, Howard University, the University of New Mexico, and the New York Public Library (including personal papers dating from 1833 to 1965). Carl Van Vechten died in New York City on December 22, 1964.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: The Carl Van Vechten Papers is the physical property of the Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library, Yale University. Literary rights, including copyright, belong to the authors or their legal heirs and assigns. For further information, consult the appropriate curator.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Gift of Carl Van Vechten and Fania Marinoff, 1941-1971. Additional material acquired through gifts and purchases is noted in folder-level acquisition notes.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Carl Van Vechten Papers. Yale Collection of American Literature, Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Carl Van Vechten Papers include correspondence, writings, photographs, scrapbooks and albums, ephemera, and artwork documenting Carl Van Vechten's activities as a writer, photographer and patron of the arts. The papers date from 1866 to 1986, and include early documents and printed items collected by Van Vechten, and material about Van Vechten and Marinoff published posthumously.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Organized into five series: I. Correspondence, 1900-1971. II. Writings, 1913-1966. Series III. Personal Papers, 1879-1971. Series IV. Art, 1866-1964. V. Printed Material, 1871-1986.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: This finding aid will be revised as additional parts of the collection are processed and as revisions in arrangement or description are made by staff.

As he prepared his personal papers to be sent to Yale, Van Vechten identified which material was to be made a part of the James Weldon Johnson Memorial Collection. Donald Gallup, the curator of the Yale Collection of American Literature, worked with Van Vechten and carried out his instructions as the Yale Library accessioned and conducted preliminary cataloging of the papers, which were subsequently classed as Za Van Vechten and JWJ Van Vechten. With few exceptions, Van Vechten's vision for his papers was maintained throughout the most recent processing of the Carl Van Vechten Papers (YCAL MSS 1050) and the Carl Van Vechten Papers Relating to African American Arts and Letters (JWJ MSS 1050). No comprehensive effort was made during the processing of the papers to amend or revise distinctions made by Van Vechten or Gallup.

Former call numbers: Za Van Vechten; Uncat Za MS 126; Uncat MSS 26; Za V375 +1; Za V375 +2; Za V375+4; Uncat Za MS 532; Uncat MSS 37; Uncat MSS 1226, Uncat Za File 57; Uncat Za File 168, Uncat Za File 172; Uncat Za File 321; Uncat Za File 482; Uncat Za File 669

relatedmaterial.head: Related Materials
relatedmaterial.p: Carl Van Vechten Papers Relating to African American Arts and Letters (JWJ MSS 1050). Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library, Yale University.
Carl Van Vechten Papers. New York Public Library, New York, New York.

bioghist.head: Fania Marinoff (1890-1971)
bioghist.p: Fania Marinoff, was born in Odessa, Russia on March 20, 1890, and came to the United States as a child with her family in the mid-1890s. After her family settled in Boston, Fania moved with her older brothers to Denver, Colorado. She began her stage career as a child in Denver, and toured with a stock company before establishing a career in New York City. She married Carl Van Vechten in 1914. Her performance as Ariel in the tercentenary revival of The Tempest in 1916 was highly praised. On Broadway she acted in productions including Arms and the Man (1915), The Streets of New York (1931), The Pillars of Society (1931), and Antony and Cleopatra (1937). She also performed in The Skin of Our Teeth at the Westport Country Playhouse in 1948. Marinoff appeared in early films including The Unsuspected Isles (1915), The Rise of Jenny Cushing (1917), and Life's Whirlpool (1917), and performed on radio broadcasts and various special stage performances. She performed less frequently after 1940, but maintained friendships with fellow actors, directors, and managers, with whom she corresponded throughout her life. Fania Marinoff died in Englewood, New Jersey on November 16, 1971.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Organized into three subseries: A-Z Correspondence; Copies of Correspondence from Other Manuscript Repositories; and Greeting Cards. A-Z Correspondence is arranged alphabetically by correspondent and chronologically within files. Correspondents represented by fewer than three letters are filed in "Letter" general files. Copies of Correspondence from Other Manuscript Repositories is arranged alphabetically by correspondent. Greeting Cards include Holiday Cards, which are arranged chronologically, and Cat-themed cards, arranged by size.

At some point in the past, library staff numbered each incoming letter from some correspondents in pencil. Where the numbering of each letter did not match the chronological ordering of the letters, current staff arranged them chronologically.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: In preparing his papers for Yale, Van Vechten often provided separate manuscript and typed notes regarding individual correspondents, and/or annotated correspondence to explain or clarify the subjects of letters. In some cases, notes refer to enclosures that were not found during processing.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Series I. Correspondence, documents Carl Van Vechten's activities as a writer, critic, photographer, collector, and supporter of the arts from the 1910s through his death in 1964. The series includes letters from and about friends, acquaintances, and business contacts who made up a social circle that included artists, writers and publishers, actors, directors, composers, musicians and singers, dancers, social activists, and others. Van Vechten's correspondence from and about African Americans may be found in the Carl Van Vechten Papers Relating to African American Arts and Letters (JWJ MSS 1050). The Carl Van Vechten Papers held by the New York Public Library contain the bulk of correspondence documenting his writing career, marriages, and family.

The correspondence consists chiefly of incoming letters. When present, Van Vechten's drafts, carbon copies, and original letters to correspondents are interfiled with incoming letters. Original letters from Van Vechten were acquired directly from the correspondent or from his or her heirs, who are noted when known. Enclosures often include newspaper and magazine clippings, performance programs, advertisements, invitations, photographs, etc. Significant enclosures and third-party letters are described in folder-level scope and content notes. Letters to Fania Marinoff are interfiled with those to Van Vechten; folder-level scope and content notes indicate when an individual's correspondence was sent only to Fania (FM).

The series includes extensive correspondence with friends Robert Downing, Bruce Kellner, Edna Kenton, Alfred and Blanche Knopf, Hugh Laing, Mabel Dodge Luhan, Mark Lutz, Leo and Kathleen Perper, Channing Pollock, Anna Marble-Pollock, Helen Channing Pollock, Karl Priebe, Aileen Pringle, James Purdy, Gertrude Stein and Alice B. Toklas, and Prentiss Taylor. The letters, in some cases written daily, relate personal and professional activities as well as news and gossip, and often include photographs, newspaper and magazine clippings, performance programs, and other ephemera.

Correspondence between Van Vechten and Gertrude Stein and Alice B. Toklas dates from 1913 to 1967, and includes exchanges regarding activities, publications, travels, and domestic life. As executor of Stein's literary estate, Van Vechten maintained files of correspondence regarding permissions to publish and perform Stein's works. Most of these files immediately follow the Stein correspondence; others are filed by the name of permission seeker in the full listing. Third-party correspondence also includes letters from mutual friends enclosed with Stein's letters, and letters from American servicemen and others who met Stein and Toklas in France and reported back to Van Vechten. Following Stein's death Alice Toklas corresponded with Van Vechten regarding requests for permission to publish Stein's works, Toklas's own publications, and her health and welfare.

Van Vechten's correspondence also documents his relationships with artists Dorothy Brett, Paul Cadmus, Miguel Covarrubias, Philip Grausman, Georgia O'Keeffe, and Florine Stettheimer; writers William Rose Benét, Karen Blixen, Witter Bynner, James Branch Cabell, Max Ewing, Arthur Davison Ficke, Lillian Hellman, Joseph Hergesheimer, Fannie Hurst, H.L. Mencken, Henry Miller, Anaïs Nin, Eugene O'Neill (and his wife Carlotta Monterey O'Neill) and Hunter Stagg; actors/directors Daniel Frohman, Lillian Gish, Helen Hayes, Alfred Lunt and Lynn Fontanne, Lawrence Langner, Armina Marshall, Mary Martin, Zachary Scott and Anna May Wong; musicians and composers Aaron Copland, Mary Garden, and Virgil Thomson; dancers and choreographers Agnes De Mille, Alicia Markova, Ted Shawn and Antony Tudor. Correspondence relating to the making of portrait photographs by Van Vechten include thank-you notes and requests for additional copies of photographs from the sitters.

Van Vechten's donations of books, manuscripts, and photographs to the Museum of the City of New York, New York Public Library, the University of New Mexico, Yale University, and other institutions and individuals are documented by letters, gift acknowledgements, lists, and other material. Correspondence relating to Van Vechten's World War II activities as a volunteer for the American Theatre Wing's Stage Door Canteen include administrative memos and letters from servicemen and fellow volunteers, as well as documents including mailing addresses, tickets, and other ephemera.

Van Vechten family correspondence includes cards and letters from Van Vechten's father, Charles Duane Van Vechten; brother Ralph Van Vechten; nephew, Van Vechten Shaffer and his wife Angevine; niece Duane Van Vechten; and an extended family member, Walter Burr Van Vechten.

Letters to Fania Marinoff chiefly relate to her acting career, including letters from playwrights, producers and directors; fellow actors; and notes and telegrams of congratulations from friends and fans. Fania Marinoff's family is represented by letters from her brother, Jacob (Jack) Marinoff and his wife Esther; nephew Nathan Marinoff and his wife Esther; brother Louis Marinoff; nephew David and his wife Rosemary; and nephew Oscar Marinoff and his wife Kate. A single letter from her father Mayer Marinoff, and letters from miscellaneous extended family members are filed under Marinoff family members. A 1901 letter from F. W. Evans to Fania's brother Michael Marinoff, and a 1916 letter from Mrs. A. B. Morgan to Fania, provide insight into Fania's youth in Denver, Colorado. Correspondence between Van Vechten and Marinoff consists of a few letters, and numerous birthday and holiday greeting cards, both commercial and hand-made.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Organized in seven subseries: Books; Articles and Essays; Reviews; Addresses and Speeches; Miscellaneous Writings; Notes; and Writings by Others. Van Vechten's writings are arranged alphabetically within each subseries. Writings by Others are arranged by name of author.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Series II, Writings, includes material documenting Van Vechten's books, articles and essays, reviews, addresses and speeches, miscellaneous writings, and notes. In addition to manuscripts, typescripts, and proofs of his writings, notes, correspondence, and clippings related to specific writings are included. The subseries Writings by Others includes works written for Van Vechten, or in his honor; two Master's theses written about Van Vechten; Coleman Dowell's stage adaptation of Van Vechten's The Tattooed Countess ; and poems and limericks collected by Van Vechten. In addition to libretti by Henry Butler for an operatic adaptation of Eugene O'Neill's Mourning Becomes Electra , vocal scores for several works by Marvin David Levy are included in the subseries. Typescript copies of Gertrude Stein's stage play Yes Is For a Very Young Man are also included.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Organized into eight subseries: Address Books; Appointment Books and Calendars; Albums and Scrapbooks; Audiovisual Material; Financial, Legal and Medical Records; Notebooks; Notes and Lists; Ephemera and Objects. Within each subseries material is identified as that of Carl Van Vechten and/or Fania Marinoff. Groups of dated items (appointment books, for example) are arranged chronologically.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Series III, Personal Papers, includes material documenting the interests and activities of Carl Van Vechten and Fania Marinoff. Daily activities are noted in appointment books and calendars, the majority dating from 1950s to 1965, and include a 1954 desk diary used by Van Vechten in 1957 to note a wide range of personal and world events which had occurred during his lifetime. Albums and scrapbooks include albums containing autographs of opera, theater, and other celebrities solicited and assembled by Van Vechten (circa 1887-1899); albums which include single photographic proof images of sitters and their autographs and/or messages to Van Vechten (1929-1964); and eighteen undated scrapbooks assembled by Van Vechten containing clippings, postcards, photographs (including those by Man Ray and Van Vechten), and other material with homoerotic and homosexual content. Van Vechten's notebooks include records of his work as a journalist in Paris in 1908-1909; bibliographical notebooks with lists of writings by Van Vechten and others; and notebooks listing his photographic sitters and subjects. Ephemera and objects include receipts, business cards, travel brochures, etc., from Van Vechten's travel in the United States and Europe; dinner party menus and recipes; and copies of Van Vechten holiday, anniversary and change of address cards. In addition to her appointment calendars dating from 1930-1936, and 1965-1970, Fania Marinoff's personal and professional activities are documented in a scrapbook of clippings, performance programs and other ephemera dating from 1934 to 1961, and notes and lists of her theatrical roles and her tour with the Blanche Walsh Company in 1901-1902. Financial, legal and medical records of Van Vechten and Marinoff consist of documents relating to the filing of federal and state taxes from 1958 to 1965; receipts for Van Vechten's stationery, bookplates, and housing for his various collections; marriage certificate, passports, and drafts of letters regarding Van Vechten's will and literary and photographic executors; and weight reduction diets recommended by Van Vechten's physician.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Arranged alphabetically by artist, followed by miscellaneous works and art reproductions.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Series IV, Art, includes portraits and caricatures of Carl Van Vechten by Martha Baker, Romaine Brooks, Miguel Covarrubias, Ruth Hammond, Florine Stettheimer, and others; watercolor drawings of Fania Marinoff in theatrical roles by Robert Evans Locher and Rollo Peters, and a statuette of Marinoff in fabric and wax by Luis Hidalgo. Additional works in a variety of media include numerous works by James Purdy; designs for Van Vechten publications by Robert Evans Locher, Ronald McRae, and Prentiss Taylor; costume and set designs; greeting card art, including a Valentine from Carrie Stettheimer; and an artist's book believed to be created by Donald Windham. Works by unidentified artists, miscellaneous prints, and art reproductions are also included.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Organized into three subseries: About Carl Van Vechten, About Fania Marinoff, and Non-Van Vechten/Marinoff Printed Material. Within each subseries material is arranged by type of material, then arranged alphabetically and/or chronologically. The non-Van Vechten/Marinoff clippings at the end of the series are arranged in broad subject categories with no chronological arrangement.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Series V, Printed Material, includes monographs; clippings from and issues of newspapers and magazines; exhibition, auction, and publishers' catalogs; event and performance programs; and advertisements and flyers. The material was collected by Carl Van Vechten and Fania Marinoff and documents their professional and social activities as well as their interests in a range of subjects. Material about Carl Van Vechten includes newspaper and magazine articles about him or that reference him; catalogs from exhibitions of his photographs; publications that include his portrait photographs; and event and performance programs in which his name appears. Material about Fania Marinoff consists chiefly of newspaper and magazine articles about her stage career, and programs from productions in which she performed. Articles about Van Vechten and Marinoff that were published posthumously were added to the papers by the collection's former curator, Donald Gallup.

The non-Van Vechten and Marinoff material consists of periodical and serial issues, performance and event programs, including music, dance, and theater performances; gallery and museum exhibit catalogs and flyers; book dealer catalogs; publishers' catalogs and flyers; advertisements and brochures; posters and broadsides; and a group of clippings on a variety of topics.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: Restricted fragile material. Reference surrogates have been substituted in the main files except for clippings relating to World War I and Edgar Saltus which were too fragile to be duplicated. For further information consult the appropriate curator.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: Box 325, Restricted Papers, is restricted until 2035. For further information consult appropriate curator.
